Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Overcoming Obstacles to Scaling-Up with a Cyberlearning Professional Development Model

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
It's About Time publishers in collaboration with the University of Colorado at Boulder develop and test a cyberlearning professional-development model that builds on the successful Curriculum Customization Service model implemented in Denver with EarthComm. The cyberlearning system is tested with the Project Based Inquiry Science (PBIS) curriculum - a proven comprehensive middle school science curriculum. In the first two years, six unit-specific materials, curriculum implementation webinars, electronic teacher editions, and teacher planning guide software are developed with teacher input and tested. In the third year, forty middle school teachers nationwide use the cyberlearning system. The learning of their students is compared to students of teachers who had other professional development. The cyberlearning system is evaluated for scalability, affordability, flexibility, and effectiveness for changing teacher practice and student learning.

In the first two years ethnographic studies done by WestEd inform the project about how teachers use the cyberlearning system and which parts are most efficacious. At the same time WestEd collects data of student learning and classroom practice from teachers who have had traditional professional development offered by the publishers. At the same time, data are gathered about student learning in classes whose teachers receive traditional professional development. These teachers form a matched control group for the teachers engaged in cyberlearning professional development in the third year. Their student learning data are compared to the learning of students whose teachers are engaged in the cyberlearning professional development. The research is evaluated by three members of the Advisory Board who have credentials in research methodology, content and broadening participation.

Effective implementation of reform-based STEM curricula depends upon curriculum-based, consistent and well developed professional development. Scaling-up to a broad-based national market is logistically constrained by traditional face-to-face professional development. The project will lead to a tested, useful, affordable, and effective system on-line system to support teacher implementation of reform science curricula that will be used by It's About Time publishers and will be available to others. The results disseminated in the research and practitioner literature can transform the professional development provided by publishers of reform science materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

Award # 1118392

Collaborative Research: Overcoming Obstacles to Scaling-Up with a Cyberlearning Professional Development Model

Tamara R Sumner, Principal Investigator, University of Colorado

Holly Devaul, Co-Principal Investigator, UCAR

 

Overview

This project designed, developed and tested an innovative cyberlearning professional development model to support reform-based science curricula at scale. A suite of online tools was developed using an iterative design cycle with input from a group of Teacher Design Advisors, as well as data from field tests in districts that were adopting the Project-Based Inquiry Science (PBIS) curriculum. The CyberPD environment (http://www.pbiscyberpd.org/) is now available as a professional development support for districts and teachers implementing any of the suite of modules that PBIS (published by It’s About Time) offers. This team’s contribution to the collaborative project was to develop a protocol for gathering teacher input into, and feedback on, the evolving online professional development environment and providing that feedback to developers. We were also responsible for selecting appropriate supplemental open educational resources for inclusion in the environment and involving teachers in the review of these resources. Additionally, we guided the development of an instrumentation specification to collect data on user behavior on the site, as well as analysis protocols and training to IAT to enable them to process and analyze teacher usage data.  

Research

We developed a multi-step scenario-guided design evaluation methodology, based on the stages of concern outlined in the Concerns-Based Adoption Model, that uses scenarios and personas to engage geographically distributed teachers in the design process. The method combines independent exploration of the online tool with a follow-up group discussion. In addition to developing and using the method, we designed a means for evaluating the effectiveness of that method in  (1) eliciting potential design issues and recommendations for change (2) helping teacher designers extend their perspectives on usability and utility to a broader range of users such as new teachers, (3) facilitating equitable participation in design feedback, and (4) yielding actionable design feedback. A custom coding scheme for characterizing teacher design advisors feedback was developed and used to analyze survey responses and transcripts of group discussions.

 Findings

The scenario-guided design evaluation method was successful in providing formative evaluation data to developers of an online tool targeted at specific intended users. It allowed for teacher advisors at distributed locations to participate productively to identify issues and make recommendations for solutions that developers could act upon. This quick and inexpensive method can identify critical navigation and usability issues prior to a more expensive field trial, so the focus there can shift to improving content and teaching practice. The method provides a structured way to focus on the features of the online tool and usefully complements evaluation efforts with classroom teachers who are actively implementing the curriculum and using the tool for teaching support.

Conclusions

For some educators transitioning to project-based teaching and learning such as the PBIS curriculum is difficult and requires a great deal of professional development and support. The CyberPD environment will have an impact in helping teachers transition to this new way of teaching and help to support national efforts to have a STEM-literate citizenry. Other projects developing online professional development support tools may benefit from using the scenario-guided design evaluation method to collect formative data on usability and utility from the perspective of their intended users. The custom coding scheme developed here can similarly be used by others to characterize feedback and discussion about the strengths and weaknesses of a developing site in a structured way.
